reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s decision to treat “target size/nature” (easy eutopia) as separable from “navigation/effort” and to analyze (1) in isolation. That methodological decomposition is present and nontrivial, so the attacked claim has some centrality, but it’s not load-bearing for the essay’s main case (which mostly argues directly that value is fragile/multiplicative and that many moral views are fussy), so centrality is moderate-low. The critique’s force is limited: it asserts inseparability but doesn’t argue concretely that the separation yields false conclusions, nor show that allowing co-evolution of navigation and target would make eutopia “easy” or substantially broaden the target. Still, it’s broadly plausible that moral/technological change can shift what is treated as the evaluative target, so it’s more correct than not. It is understandable but a bit underspecified about what exactly changes (concept of eutopia? feasibility? evaluative standard?) and how that affects the essay’s probability/target-width claims.
title: Navigation toward eutopia may redefine the target itself
